questions.text: A 23-year-old man was admitted with confusion. He was noted to have Kayser-Fleischer rings, and his liver function tests were consistent with acute hepatitis. Which chromosome contains the gene for this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gene involved in Wilson's disease is located on chromosome 13.

  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that results in copper deposition in the liver and brain and impaired incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.
  • Wilson's disease is a cause of acute liver failure and can also lead to decompensated cirrhosis. Patients with neurological disease often have Kayser-Fleischer rings.
  • In the majority of patients, plasma ceruloplasmin is low (< 200 mg/L); serum copper is < 11 micromol/L, and in 65% of patients 24 24-hour urinary copper is elevated at > 3 micromol.
  • Liver biopsy will aid the diagnosis.
  • Treatment includes D-penicillamine, which leads to urinary copper excretion.

Chromosome 6 (Option A): 90% of cases of haemochromatosis are caused by the substitution of tyrosine for cysteine at position 282 of the HFE gene found on chromosome 6.

Chromosome 15 (Option C): Marfan's syndrome is caused by defects in fibrillin; the gene responsible is located on chromosome 15.

Chromosome 17 (Option D): Neurofibromatosis type 1 is due to a mutation or deletion of the NF1 gene located on chromosome 17.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is referred from the Emergency Department with a paracetamol overdose. Which of the following is an indication for liver transplantation in acute liver failure as a result of paracetamol overdose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prothrombin time > 100 seconds in acute liver failure with paracetamol poisoning is one of the selection criteria for liver transplantation.

The remainder of the selection criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure with paracetamol overdose are as follows:

  • Arterial pH < 7.3 (this needs to be interpreted with caution as pH may improve with N-acetylcysteine and rehydration) (Option A ruled out)
  • Creatinine > 2.5 mg/dL (Option C ruled out)
  • Grade III or grade IV encephalopathy.

Serum bilirubin > 15 mg/dl (Option B) is part of the selection criteria for liver transplantation in non-paracetamol induced acute liver failure.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is referred with abnormal liver function and undergoes a liver biopsy. Which of the following count against hepatic cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granuloma formation is not classically seen in cirrhosis. Granuloma formation represents a localised collection of macrophages (often epithelioid in appearance) and is not a hallmark of cirrhosis, but is seen in diseases like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, etc.

Key Histological Features Supportive of Cirrhosis:

  • Fibrous Septa Formation: (Option A)
    • A hallmark of progressing fibrosis.
    • These fibrotic bands bridge portal tracts and central veins, leading to architectural distortion of the liver.
    • Seen in stage 3 and 4 fibrosis, including cirrhosis.
  • Nodular Regeneration: (Option D)
    • Regenerating hepatocyte nodules surrounded by fibrous tissue are characteristic of cirrhosis.
    • This leads to the classic "nodular" appearance seen grossly and microscopically.
  • Liver Cell Necrosis: (Option C)
    • Often present in chronic liver diseases, including those progressing to cirrhosis.
    • Ongoing hepatocyte death contributes to inflammation, fibrosis, and regeneration.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with confusion and drowsiness. A diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy is suspected, and treatment with lactulose is begun. Which of the following concerning lactulose is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lactulose, an osmotic laxative, inhibits the proliferation of ammonia-forming organisms in the gut

In the management of hepatic encephalopathy, lactulose has a number of actions to help reduce gut ammonia production and absorption. Production of a more acidic colonic pH is key in this.

These mechanisms are:

  • Conversion of lactulose to lactic acid acidifies the gut lumen, which favours oxidation of NH4+ to NH3 and the passage of NH3from tissues into the lumen. (Option B ruled out)
  • The acidic pH inhibits the proliferation of ammonia-producing microbes and promotes colonisation by non-ammonia-producing bacteria such as lactobacilli.
  • The laxative effect leads to an overall reduction in colonic bacterial loadand reduction in the protein load absorbed from the gut.

Lactulose is a non-absorbable disaccharide, which is hence safe to use in diabetics. (Options A & C)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has ingested an unknown quantity of paracetamol tablets four hours ago. She now presents with nausea, vomiting, anorexia and right subchondral pain. Which of the following features suggests that she should be transferred to the liver transplant centre?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The serum creatinine level of more than 3.4mg/dL is a poor prognostic factor for this patient.

  • Paracetamol is hepatotoxic in overdose due to the accumulation of a toxic metabolite: NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine).
  • Under normal conditions, NAPQI is detoxified by glutathione, but in overdose, glutathione stores are depleted, allowing NAPQI to bind to hepatocyte proteins, leading to massive hepatocellular necrosis.
  • Liver failure may result, with associated metabolic acidosis, coagulopathy, hypoglycemia, and encephalopathy.

The King's College criteria for transfer to a facility for liver transplant are:

  • Encephalopathy (Grade III or IV) (Option A)
  • Serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dl
  • Blood pH <7.3 (Option D)
  • Elevated lactate (>3.5 mmol/L despite fluid resuscitation) (Option C)

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441917/

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for jaundice and liver fibrosis. His AST-57 and ALT-81 IU/mL and serological tests are given below. Which of the following is the next step in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most appropriate next step is to confirm active HCV infection by performing HCV RNA RT-PCR.

  • The positive anti-HCV antibody suggests past or current exposure to the hepatitis C virus.
  • However, this alone does not confirm active infection.
  • The absence of HBsAg along with anti-HBc IgG positivity indicates resolved past hepatitis B infection, not active HBV disease.
  • Given the elevated liver enzymes and presence of fibrosis, ongoing liver damage is likely, and the active cause must be identified.
  • To confirm chronic HCV infection, HCV RNA by RT-PCR should be performed.
  • This test will detect whether the virus is actively replicating.
  • Detection of HCV RNA confirms active infection and justifies initiating antiviral treatment.

Standard Indications for Therapy in HCV:

  • All patients with chronic HCV infection (detectable HCV RNA,with or without elevated ALT) except for those with short life expectancies owing to comorbid conditions.
  • Any stage of fibrosis; pretreatment biopsy is no longer embraced and has been supplanted by noninvasive measures, e.g., imaging to determine liver elasticity.
  • Responsiveness in groups previously refractory to interferon-based therapy is not diminished by contemporary direct-acting oral combination regimens.

HBV DNA (Option A): Not indicated since HBsAg is negative, suggesting no active HBV replication.

Anti-HBsAg (Option B): Measures immunity status to HBV but has no role in this patient's current evaluation.

Liver biopsy (Option D): Invasive and not needed for diagnosis or treatment initiation in HCV. Non-invasive methods are preferred.

Treatment regimens for HCV genotypes:

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended for a newborn born to a mother suffering from acute viral hepatitis B infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HBIG is indicated for newborn infants of HBsAg-positive mothers, with initiation of the vaccine series at the same time, both within 12 hours of birth (administered at different injection sites).

  • Perinatal transmission is a key factor in the continued high prevalence of hepatitis B.
  • This type of transmission mainly occurs when the mother is chronically infected with hepatitis B or has an acute infection during the third trimester or early postpartum period.
  • Although about 10% of cases may be acquired in utero, most infections occur around the time of delivery.
  • Breastfeeding is not a route of transmission and is not contraindicated in mothers with HBV.
  • The risk of perinatal HBV transmission is strongly associated with the mother's viral load and HBeAg status:
  • ~90% of HBeAg-positive mothers transmit the virus to their newborns.
  • Only 10-15% of anti-HBe-positive mothers do so.
  • Most neonates infected perinatally have no symptoms during the acute phase, but many go on to develop chronic infection.
  • To prevent perinatal transmission, post-exposure prophylaxis is recommended for infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers:
  • A single intramuscular dose (0.5 mL) of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) should be given in the thigh immediately after birth.
  • This should be followed by a complete 3-dose series of the hepatitis B vaccine, starting within the first 12 hours of life.

Tenofovir (Option B) is indicated in the management of chronic hepatitis B infection

questions.solution:
Explanation:

HEV is a major cause of acute hepatitis throughout Central and Southeast Asia (about 16% of the population there has antibodies to the virus), and it should be considered in patients with acute hepatitis after a trip to an endemic area.

  • Adults: HEV

questions.text: Parenteral Vitamin K is given to a patient with jaundice, but PT remains unchanged. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The probable cause here is cirrhosis (synthesis is affected) since the prothrombin time doesn't improve even after parenteral vitamin K administration.

Role of Clotting Factors and the Liver:

  • Nearly all coagulation factors, except factor VIII, are synthesised in the liver.
  • These factors have a short serum half-life-from about 6 hours (factor VII) to 5 days (fibrinogen)-making them reliable indicators of acute liver synthetic function.

Prothrombin Time (PT) as a Diagnostic Tool:

  • PT assesses the levels of factors II, V, VII, and X, all of which are dependent on both hepatic synthesis and vitamin K for production.
  • A prolonged PT indicates a deficiency or dysfunction of these factors and is used to evaluate liver function.

Vitamin K and PT Correction:

  • In conditions like obstructive jaundice or fat malabsorption, vitamin K absorption is impaired.
  • Supplementing with parenteral vitamin K can restore clotting factor synthesis and normalise PT.
  • However, if PT remains prolonged despite vitamin K administration, it indicates that the liver is unable to synthesise clotting factors, even when vitamin K is available.
  • In cirrhosis, the liver's synthetic capacity is significantly impaired due to chronic structural damage.
  • As a result, even if vitamin K is provided, the liver cannot produce adequate clotting factors, leading to persistent prolongation of PT.

Obstructive Jaundice (Option A): Vitamin K deficiency occurs due to poor bile flow, impairing fat-soluble vitamin absorption. But PT typically improves after vitamin K is given.

Hemolytic Jaundice (Option C): Caused by breakdown of red blood cells, not liver dysfunction. PT is usually normal, and vitamin K has no major role.

Biliary Atresia (Option D): Affects infants and results in obstructive-type jaundice, which may respond to parenteral vitamin K if liver function is still intact.

questions.text:
In the evaluation of liver functions, a ratio of AST/ALT > 1 is seen in which of the following conditions?
I. Alcoholic hepatitis
II. Non Alcoholic Steatohepatitis
III. Covid 19 infection
IV. Autoimmune hepatitis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In most cases of acute hepatocellular injury, ALT levels are equal to or higher than AST.
  • In chronic viral hepatitis and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), the AST: ALT ratio is usually less than 1.
  • However, as liver damage progresses to cirrhosis, this ratio often increases to greater than 1.
  • An AST: ALT ratio greater than 2:1 is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease, and aratio above 3:1 is highly suggestive.
  • In alcoholic liver disease, AST levels typically do not exceed 300 IU/L, and ALT may remain normal.
  • This low ALT is partly due to alcohol-induced deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate, a cofactor necessary for ALT activity.

questions.text: The Milan criteria are used for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In transplantation medicine, the Milan criteria are applied as a basis for selecting patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation.

The Milan criteria state that a patient is selected for transplantation when he or she has:

  • One lesion smaller than 5 cm.
  • Up to 3 lesions smaller than 3 cm
  • No extrahepatic manifestations
  • No vascular invasion

Acetaminophen toxicity (Option B): The King's College Criteria are well-accepted criteria that show the degree of multiorgan dysfunction from acetaminophen-induced liver failure & evaluate the need for transplantation in liver failure secondary to acetaminophen overdose.

Cirrhosis staging (Option C): Child Pugh scoring is used for staging cirrhosis

Hepatic encephalopathy staging (Option D): The West Haven criteria are used to stage hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which one of the following is least expected to precipitate hepatic encephalopathy in a liver cirrhosis patient:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A peritoneal tap is least expected to precipitate hepatic encephalopathy.

Factors precipitating hepatic encephalopathy:

  • Nitrogen load (GI bleed, protein load from food intake, renal failure, constipation) (Option B)
  • Drugs (narcotics, CNS depressants)
  • Electrolyte disturbance (hypokalemia, alkalosis, hypoxia, hypovolemia) (Option D)
  • Infection (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis) (Option C)
  • Deterioration in hepatic function or superimposed liver disease
  • Spontaneous portosystemic shunts (e.g. splenorenal shunts) or intentional portosystemic shunts (e.g. TIPS)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will cause ascites with a serum ascites albumin gradient > 1.1g/dL and a high ascitic protein concentration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Constrictive pericarditis causes ascites due to portal hypertension (hence high SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL), and because the hepatic sinusoids are intact, the ascitic protein concentration remains high (≥2.5 g/dL)-a pattern typical of cardiac ascites.

  • The Serum-ascites Albumin gradient (SAAG) is useful for distinguishing ascites caused by portal hypertension from non-portal hypertensive ascites.
  • SAAG (Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient) helps determine whether portal hypertension is the cause of ascites.
    • SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL → Suggests portal hypertension.
    • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Indicates non-portal hypertensive causes.
  • Ascitic fluid protein concentration gives additional clues:
    • Ascitic protein ≥ 2.5 g/dL → Suggests intact hepatic sinusoids, allowing more protein into the fluid (e.g., cardiac ascites, early Budd-Chiari, constrictive pericarditis).
    • Ascitic protein < 2.5 g/dL → Suggests damaged or fibrosed sinusoids, as in cirrhosis or advanced Budd-Chiari.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option B) causes loss of protein through the kidneys, hence causes a low SAAG ratio in ascites

Tuberculous peritonitis (Option C) will cause an exudative ascites, which will result in loss of protein from the serum into the peritoneum; hence low SAAG ratio ascites level.

questions.text: Which of the following regions of the abdomen is preferred for abdominal paracentesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lower quadrants are the most frequent sites for paracentesis. The left lower quadrant is preferred because of the greater depth of ascites and the thinner abdominal wall.

  • Paracentesis is a safe procedure even in patients with coagulopathy.
  • Complications, including abdominal wall hematomas, hypotension, hepatorenal syndrome, and infection, are infrequent.
  • Cirrhosis accounts for 84% of cases of ascites.
  • Cardiac ascites, peritoneal carcinomatosis, and 'mixed' ascites resulting from cirrhosis and a second disease account for 10-15% of cases

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is not useful in the assessment of acute liver injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Albumin is not useful in the assessment of acute liver injury.

  • Serum albumin has a long half-life: 18-20 days, with ~4% degraded per day.
  • Because of this slow turnover, the serum albumin is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction; only minimal changes in the serum albumin are seen in acute liver conditions such as viral hepatitis, drug-related hepatotoxicity, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Hypoalbuminemia is more common in chronic liver disorders such as cirrhosis and usually reflects severe liver damage and decreased albumin synthesis.

The aminotransferases (transaminases) (Option A) are sensitive indicators of liver cell injury and are most helpful in recognising acute hepatocellular diseases such as hepatitis.

The prothrombin time (Option B) may be elevated in hepatitis and cirrhosis, as well as in disorders that lead to vitamin K deficiency, such as obstructive jaundice or fat malabsorption.

Alkaline phosphatase (Option C): The activities of three enzymes-alkaline phosphatases, 5'-nucleotidase, and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)-are usually elevated in cholestasis.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are used to calculate Maddrey's Discriminant Function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serum bilirubin is one of the parameters used to calculate Maddrey's Discriminant Factor.

Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) is a prognostic scoring tool used to assess the severity and short-term mortality risk in patients with alcoholic hepatitis, helping guide treatment decisions such as the need for corticosteroid therapy.

The formula for MDF:

MDF=4.6×(Prothrombin time prolongation above control in seconds)+Serum bilirubin (mg/dL)

Parameters Used in the Calculation:

  • Serum Bilirubin (mg/dL)
    • Directly included in the MDF formula.
    • Reflects liver function and severity of hepatic dysfunction.
  • Prothrombin Time (PT)
    • The difference between the patient's PT and the control PT is used.
    • Indicates impaired liver synthetic function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parameter used to calculate the MELD score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Albumin is not a parameter of the MELD scoring system.

Parameters used to assess MELD score (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) (CBI) are:

  • Creatinine
  • Bilirubin
  • INR
  • Utility: A prognostic tool that predicts 6-month mortality. The MELD score has been shown to:
    • Reduce waiting list mortality
    • Reduce waiting time before transplantation
    • To be the best predictor of pretransplantation mortality
  • Patients with cirrhosis are typically candidatesfor liver transplantation once their biologic Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is ≥15
  • In 2016, the MELD score was modified to incorporate serum sodium, another important predictor of survival in liver transplantation candidates (the MELD-Na score).
  • The Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) score is used for children (<12 years old)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding laboratory findings of Zieve's Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Zieve's syndrome is associated with dyslipidemia, acanthocytes, and raised bilirubin.

Zieve's Syndrome

Zieve's Syndrome is a rare but well-recognised condition associated with severe alcohol-induced liver injury, especially alcoholic hepatitis.

It presents with a triad of:

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Hyperlipidemia (Dyslipidemia)
  • Jaundice

Key Laboratory Features:

  • Hemolytic Anaemia:
    • Results from the destruction of red blood cells.
    • Characteristic spur cells (acanthocytes) are often seen on a peripheral smear.
    • May contribute to elevated unconjugated bilirubin, leading to jaundice.
  • Dyslipidemia:
    • Elevated triglycerides and cholesterol are common findings.
    • This lipid disturbance is a hallmark feature of Zieve's syndrome.
  • Bilirubin:
    • Although bilirubin may be normal in some liver diseases, in Zieve's syndrome, it is typically elevated due to hemolysis and liver dysfunction. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Portal hypertension is defined as a hepatic venous pressure gradient above __mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) to >5 mm Hg.

Definition:

Portal hypertension is diagnosed when the hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) exceeds 5 mmHg.

Main Contributing Mechanisms:

  • Increased Resistance in the Liver:
    • Blood flow is obstructed within the liver due to structural changes such as cirrhosis, regenerative nodules, and microvascular blockages (e.g., microthrombi).
  • Enhanced Blood Flow from the Gut:
    • There is vasodilation in the splanchnic circulation (i.e., blood vessels supplying the gastrointestinal tract), which leads to increased portal blood inflow.
  • Combined Effect:
    • Both mechanical obstruction inside the liver and increased splanchnic inflow contribute to the elevated pressure in the portal venous system.
  • Clinically significantportal hypertension is defined as an HVPG ≥10 mmHg when there is a substantial risk of decompensation with variceal bleeding.
  • Cirrhosis is the most common cause of portal hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following leads to postsinusoidal hepatic portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Veno-occlusive syndrome leads to Hepatic sinusoidal obstruction and causes portal hypertension.

Budd-Chiari syndrome and constrictive pericarditis (Options A and C) are posthepatic causes of portal hypertension.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Option D) is a sinusoidal hepatic cause.
